segments.content: Covariance matrix estimation in high-dimensional factor models, particularly for idiosyncratic components driven by non-pervasive factors, is a complex problem that requires structured estimators to ensure positive-definite estimates in the low-dimension-low-sample-size setting, while exploiting common structures within the idiosyncratic components to improve performance and identify weak factors within clusters.

The latent factor model for a p-dimensional random vector of asset returns, where factors, idiosyncratic components, and their correlations are estimated from observable data, assumes uncorrelated idiosyncratic and common factors, with the idiosyncratic covariance having a block-diagonal structure when assets are sorted by cluster membership, and requires restrictions on the covariance matrix elements to ensure factor and factor loading identifiability.

The paper focuses on developing block-diagonal estimators for estimating idiosyncratic covariance matrices in high-dimensional cases, addressing estimation bias and ensuring positive-definiteness, while considering the clustering patterns of financial assets. The estimators are formulated as linear combinations of covariance matrices and block-diagonal idiosyncratic covariance estimates, with the structure of the indicator matrix determining the blocks. The linear shrinkage method is used to optimize the bias-variance trade-off, aiming for no constraints on sample size and number of clusters.

To evaluate the performance of estimators in identifying true patterns of block-diagonal structure in idiosyncratic covariance, simulations are conducted with known population covariance matrices, constructing common and idiosyncratic covariances, and measuring accuracy using various performance measures, including recall, precision, accuracy, and F1 score, as well as clustering and portfolio optimization scenarios, considering both simulation and historical data.

The study focuses on simulating time series of asset returns using the student's t-distribution with 5 degrees of freedom and zero mean, to replicate the heavy-tailed property observed in real-world data. The simulations are repeated 250 times, with varying number of factors (k) and idiosyncratic covariance structures (m). The average linkage function outperforms in all aspects, and the CSH estimator based on average linkage is chosen for its flexibility and ability to handle both block-diagonal and partial block-diagonal covariance structures. The estimators are tested on historical data using a portfolio optimization approach, and the results show that clustering-based methods generally outperform thresholding-based methods, with the exception of the soft thresholding estimator for lower-dimensional cases. The study also examines the shapes of the identified idiosyncratic covariances for a specific time window in historical data, demonstrating the flexibility and robustness of the clustering-based approach.

The paper proposes a unified approach to estimate the block-diagonal idiosyncratic covariance matrix in high-dimensional financial return time series, focusing on the idiosyncratic component under the assumption that assets form clusters, which improves upon the thresholding-based approach by capturing more realistic asset return dependence and potentially enhancing portfolio volatility management. The proposed estimators utilize a clustering-based hierarchical clustering method to identify the clusters and employ an iterative cross-validation procedure to estimate the block structure (clusters) and the sparse idiosyncratic covariance matrix. The results demonstrate the superiority of the proposed approach compared to the industry-based estimator, with the clusters identified differing from the industry classification but resulting in comparable or better portfolio performance.
